title: What friend told her best pal when she rang at 7.15am - to reveal they HAD won Lotto jackpot of £15m
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A LOTTERY winner who made an early morning call to tell her best friend they’d scooped £15 million was warned: ‘You better be calling me to tell me we have won the lottery’. 
Paula Barraclough, 45, and Lorraine Smith, 54 – known to each other as Polly and Lolly – won £15,342,900 and will share the winnings after buying the tickets with spare change. PA:Press Association Two best friends Paula Barraclough, 45, and Lorraine Smith, 54, from Tyne and Wear celebrate at the Lumley Castle hotel in Chester-le-Street after scooping the £15,342,900 jackpot in last Saturday’s Lotto draw PA:Press Association 6 The winners, who have been friends for 17 years and refer to each other as Polly and Lolly, won the £15,342,900 on a syndicate ticket 
Ms Barraclough said she learned of the win when her friend called her at 7.15am on Sunday morning. 
The coffee shop worker, who lives at home with her parents, said: “I picked up the phone and said to her: ‘You better be calling me to tell me we have won the lottery waking me up at this time.’ 
“And the voice on the other end of the phone replied: ‘We have! We have all six numbers.'” related stories LUCKY GIRL Lottery whinger Jane Park is in talks to star on Love Island after controversial appearance on Loose Women LOTTO 'DRY RUN' Friend claims rapist Edward Putman tricked friends with another 'fake' lottery win months before his jackpot LOTTO WHINGER Lottery winner goes on Loose Women to say her fortune doesn't make her 'completely unhappy' BIG SPENDER Who is Jane Park? Everything you need to know about Britain's youngest EuroMillions winner LOTTO DAD'S DRIVING DILEMMA Dad who scooped £250k on lottery can't wait to buy an Audi A3 - but there's one problem 
She added: “I just fell silent – I couldn’t quite believe what I was hearing.” 
She said the win was “life-changing” and she hope to move into a house of her own. 
Now the two pals say first class flights to Las Vegas is top of their shopping list – as well as a frying pan. 
The pair – who have been friends for more than 17 years – have won £7.6m each but neither will give up their jobs, The Chronicle reports. 
Lorraine said: “I literally threw my old frying pan away the day before I became a multi-millionaire so a new frying pan will definitely be one of the first things I will be buying.” PA:Press Association Ms Smith only bought the Lucky Dip ticket from a local shop as she was waiting for her bus to work 
The winning ticket was bought from Mccoll Newsagent on Park Lane in Sunderland. 
Care home cook Ms Smith, who lost her husband six years ago, only bought the Lucky Dip ticket from a local shop as she was waiting for her bus to work, which was running late. 
The mum-of-one said: “The news really is still sinking in. 
“I thought I was hallucinating – I just thought this cannot really be happening. 
“It was only when I got on the phone to Camelot I realised my best friend and I really were multi-millionaires.” PA:Press Association Beverley Doran celebrates scooping a £14,509,500 jackpot prize on last Friday’s EuroMillions draw SWNS:South West News Service 6 The home of Beverley Doran who is celebrating after winning £14,509,500 last Friday 
Single mum Beverley Doran, 37, cancelled her benefit payments of £320 per week – which she has relied on for the past two years. 
Today she told her neighbours to help themselves to her sofa and washing machine. 
Full time carer Bev was forced to give up her job as a receptionist after two of her children were diagnosed with autism in 2015 – within months of each other. 
Today Bev, who has four children aged 17, 10, nine and five, said she hopes to up sticks from her three-bed council house and has already been looking for her next abode in Shipley, West Yorks. 
She said: “It’s been a struggle financially – the benefit woman nearly dropped the phone when I told her I’d won the lottery.” 
Bev added: “It’s overwhelming to think that I won’t have to struggle again. Before all my money went on the children and I went around in rags. 
“I could now even buy a plane! I suffered with depression just worrying about what was going to happen to my children. 
“I’m still waiting for someone to come and burst my bubble.” PA:Press Association 6 Full time carer Bev was forced to give up her job as a receptionist but is now a millionaire 
Lucky Bev of Shipley, West Yorks, discovered she had become a millionaire while lying in bed checking her phone on Saturday morning. 
Lucky Bev, , won £50 in Wednesday’s draw and decided to make the most of her good luck so she bought a EuroMillions lucky dip ticket online. 
But because she’s allergic to champagne – which turns her ”red like a lobster” if she takes a sip – Bev treated herself to a luxury weekend in Harrogate, North Yorks. 
She said: “I could see the jackpot amount but couldn’t work out what I’d won. Then I slowly realised it was one UK winner and that that person was me. 
“I babbled to my son and collapsed on the floor and started crying and shaking. 
“I rang my mum who was in the shower and she didn’t believe me – it’s just been a rollercoaster.”
